proof:
We begin by defining $\mathcal{H} := \text{PARTITION}(G_{Base}, g)$ and constructing the graph $H_{Base}$ as the union of the subgraphs of $G_{Base}$ induced by the sets in $\mathcal{H}$, i.e., $H_{Base} := \bigcup_{S \in \mathcal{H}} G_{Base}[S]$. The proof proceeds by considering two cases based on the value of $d_{comp}$.

First, consider the case where $d_{comp} < g$. For this scenario, we define the distribution $\mathcal{H}$ to be $\mathcal{G}(H_{Base}, \frac{d_{comp}}{g}, g)$. By the construction of this distribution, for any graph $H$ in its support, the maximum degree is bounded by $\Delta(H) \le 2 \cdot \frac{d_{comp}}{g} \cdot g = 2 \cdot d_{comp}$. This establishes Item 1.
The chosen parameters $p = \frac{d_{comp}}{g}$ and $d = g$ satisfy the preconditions for the Compression Lemma. Specifically, the condition $4 \ln(2n) \le d_{comp} < g$ implies that $p = \frac{d_{comp}}{g}$ is in the interval $(0,1)$. Furthermore, we have $d=g > \Delta(H_{Base})$, since each component subgraph has at most $g$ vertices. It also holds that $d=g = \frac{d_{comp}}{d_{comp}/g} > \frac{4 \ln(2n)}{p}$. Thus, the parameters $p$ and $d$ meet the required constraints.
Consequently, we can apply the Compression Lemma, which guarantees the existence of a message $\phi$ for which the missed-edge graph $H_{Miss}(\phi) = (V, E_{Miss}(\phi))$ has a bounded number of edges:
$$|E_{Miss}(\phi)| \le \frac{\ln(2) \cdot (s+1) \cdot g}{d_{comp}}$$
Next, we apply the $\text{SPLIT}$ function to $H_{Miss}(\phi)$ with the parameter $d_{filter}$, yielding a pair of vertex sets $(L,Q)$. According to Proposition 3.3, the size of $Q$ is bounded by $|Q| \le \frac{2|E_{Miss}(\phi)|}{d_{filter}}$, which in turn is at most $\frac{2 \ln(2) \cdot (s+1) g}{d_{comp} \cdot d_{filter}}$. This proves Item 5.
We then define the collection of vertex sets $\mathcal{P}$ as $\{S \cap L : S \in \mathcal{H}\}$. Since $\mathcal{H}$ is a partition of $V$ and $Q$ is the complement of $L$ in $V$, the collection $\mathcal{P} \cup \{Q\}$ forms a partition of $V$. By Fact 2.1, the size of $\mathcal{P}$ is equal to the size of $\mathcal{H}$, so $|\mathcal{P}| = |\mathcal{H}| \le \lceil \frac{n}{g} \rceil$, which proves Item 4.
It remains to verify the properties for every set $P \in \mathcal{P}$. Let $X_P$ denote the subgraph $H_{Miss}(\phi)[P]$.
*   From Proposition 3.3, because $P \subseteq L$, we have $\Delta(X_P) \le \Delta(H_{Miss}(\phi)[L]) \le d_{filter}$. This confirms Item 3.
*   By definition, any $P \in \mathcal{P}$ is a subset of some $S \in \mathcal{H}$. Our initial construction of $H_{Base}$ ensures that $H_{Base}[S] = G_{Base}[S]$. As $P$ is a subset of $S$, it follows that $H_{Base}[P] = G_{Base}[P]$, proving Item 2.

Second, consider the case where $d_{comp} \ge g$. In this situation, we set the distribution to be $\mathcal{H} = \mathcal{G}(H_{Base}, 1, |V|)$. We define $\mathcal{P} = \mathcal{H}$, which implies that $Q = \emptyset$. An empty set for $Q$ trivially satisfies the size constraint in Item 5. This choice of parameters makes the distribution $\mathcal{H}$ deterministic, with its support containing only the single graph $H_{Base}$. The maximum degree of $H_{Base}$ is at most $g$ (since each component in $\mathcal{H}$ has at most $g$ vertices), and since $g \le d_{comp}$, we have $\Delta(H_{Base}) \le g \le 2 \cdot d_{comp}$. This satisfies Item 1. As $|\mathcal{P}| = |\mathcal{H}|$, Item 4 follows directly from Fact 2.1. Because the support of $\mathcal{H}$ is just $\{H_{Base}\}$, there is no ambiguity for the compressor, so the missed-edge graph is empty, $H_{Miss}(\phi) = \emptyset$. This proves Item 3. Finally, by our definitions of $\mathcal{P}$ and $H_{Base}$, for any $P \in \mathcal{P}$, the equality $G_{Base}[P] = H_{Base}[P]$ holds, which verifies Item 2.
